20,000 FRENCH FELINES STOLEN; CAT-SKINNING TRADE SUSPECTED

 By JOHN LICHFIELD  
 c.2000 The Independent, London  
 (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  

   PARIS _ Over 20,000 cats a year are being stolen in France, many
of them ending up as baby's shoes or luxury slippers.

   French animal lovers believe that the cat rustling is the work
of professionally organized gangs, who work in almost complete
impunity. Police say they have little time to devote to such a low
profile crime.

   It is feared that some of the cats are being stolen to provide
helpless victims to train attack dogs or to amuse their sadistic
owners.

   Many others, it is known, are being taken for their fur. A raid
on a tannery in Deux Sevres in western France discovered 1,500 cat
skins, which were being used to make baby's shoes.

   Anne Vesgien, a cat lover who is herself a magistrate and
president of an association which campaigns for a better legal
status for pets in France and other EU countries, said: ``These
offenses are more and more common and can lead to acts of torture
and terrible acts of barbarity, even if many people seem to find
the whole thing funny.

   ``We move heaven and earth for a stolen car or painting but, in
these cases, nothing is done.''

   A Socialist member of parliament and veterinarian, Genevieve
Perrin-Gaillard, is to press for new tougher laws on the
identification of cats and dogs in France in an attempt to give
police and judicial authorities more weapons against pet rustlers.

   Under a 1989 law, all cats and dogs have to be tattooed with
their identity before they can be sold, or given to another person,
but this law has proved impossible to enforce.

   One bereaved cat owner in Toulouse told the newspaper, Le
Figaro: ``A neighbor saw a white car stop in front of our house. A
young woman with rubber gloves caught my cat in a sheet and then
shoved it into a basket. The car drove away quickly... since then
we can only imagine the worst.''

   The Societe pour la Protection des Animaux _ the French
equivalent of the SPCA _ says that it has been inundated with
reports of stolen cats from all corners of France. Some have simply
strayed from home but the organization puts the number of
suspicious cases at at least 20,000 a year and rising.
